```{r}
# ----------------------------------------------------
# 1. Load Required Libraries
# ----------------------------------------------------
# install.packages(c("ggplot2", "scales", "here"))
library(ggplot2)
library(scales)
library(here)

# ----------------------------------------------------
# 2. Read the CSV data
# ----------------------------------------------------
file_path <- here("official_dataset_heaps_law_paper-reduced.csv")
rawdata   <- read.csv(file_path, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# ----------------------------------------------------
# 3. Define Your Custom Colors
#    Using the first three 'hue_pal' colors:
#    gg_red <- hex[1], gg_green <- hex[2], gg_blue <- hex[3]
# ----------------------------------------------------
hex      <- hue_pal()(3)
gg_red   <- hex[1]
gg_green <- hex[2]
gg_blue  <- hex[3]

# Custom color palette (using red and blue only)
my_palette <- c(
  "open"   = gg_red,
  "closed" = gg_blue
)

# ----------------------------------------------------
# 4. Plot: x = alpha, y = beta, color by vocab
# ----------------------------------------------------
p <- ggplot(rawdata, aes(x = alpha, y = beta, color = vocab)) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = my_palette, labels = c("Open", "Closed")) +
  labs(
    x     = "Alpha",
    y     = "Beta",
    color = "Vocabulary"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position      = c(0.99, 0.99),
    legend.justification = c("right", "top"),
    legend.background    = element_rect(fill = "gray95", color = NA),
    plot.margin          = unit(c(1, 1, 1, 1), "cm")
  )

# ----------------------------------------------------
# 5. Print or Save the Plot
# ----------------------------------------------------
# Display the plot
print(p)

# Save the plot to a PDF with transparent background
ggsave(
  filename = "alpha_vs_beta_plot.png",
  plot     = p,
  device   = "png",
  width    = 6,
  height   = 6,
  bg       = "transparent"
)

```
